qas.question: When do police often use unmarked cars?

answers.text: primarily for sting operations or apprehending criminals without alerting them to their presence

qas.question: Why did New York State ban marked cars for traffic cops?

context: Unmarked vehicles are used <a0_0><b4_0>primarily for sting operations or apprehending criminals without alerting them to their presence<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Some police forces use unmarked or minimally marked cars <a1_0><b5_0>for traffic law enforcement<b5_0/><a1_0/>, since drivers slow down at the sight of marked police vehicles and unmarked vehicles make it easier for officers to catch speeders and traffic violators. This practice is controversial, with for example, New York State banning this practice in <a2_0><b6_0>1996<b6_0/><a2_0/> on the grounds that <a3_0><b7_0><b8_0>it endangered motorists who might be pulled over by people impersonating police officers<b8_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/>.
